title: What is contamination
body: Contamination is anything in food that should not be there. It can be biological (bacteria, viruses), chemical (cleaner residues, allergens), or physical (glass, metal, stones).

title: Biological hazards
body: Bacteria, viruses and moulds are biological hazards. They multiply quickly in warm, moist foods and can make guests seriously ill. Keep raw and ready-to-eat food apart, cook to safe core temperatures, chill high-risk food within 90 minutes and monitor dates closely.

title: Physical hazards
body: Physical hazards are objects that can injure or choke guests: broken glass, packaging, stones, jewellery or pest droppings. Keep kit in good repair, cover food in storage, check deliveries, and use colour-coded cloths to avoid fragments entering food.

title: Allergen hazards & cross-contact
body: Allergen proteins are hazardous even in tiny amounts. Cross-contact happens when tools, cloths or hands move allergen traces onto food that should be safe. Use separate utensils, clean and disinfect between tasks, and check the allergen matrix before answering guest questions.

title: High-risk foods and why they matter
body: Ready-to-eat foods that support bacterial growth (cooked meats, dairy, cooked rice) are high risk. Keep them cold (5 C or below), minimise handling, and protect from raw foods.

title: Barriers that prevent contamination
body: Separate equipment for raw and ready foods, correct storage order, clean-as-you-go, and effective hand hygiene create multiple barriers. If one fails, another catches it.

title: Allergen disclosure on the till
stem: A customer asks if the soup contains celery. The recipe sometimes changes.

options.label: Say it's fine; you made it yesterday
options.result: Incorrect. Never guess allergen content. You must check an up-to-date allergen matrix or label.

options.result: Correct. Always verify against the current recipe or product label.
